legal_basis: Notice is given under section 1 of the Statistics of Trade Act 1947.
title: Annual Business Survey

title.text: You are completing this for {ru_name} {trad_as}

description.text: If the company details or structure have changed contact us on {telephone_number_link} or email {email_link}

list: You have been selected to complete the Annual Business Survey (ABS).
We will treat your data securely and confidentially.
You cannot appeal your selection. Your business was selected to give us a comprehensive view of the UK economy.
You still need to complete this survey even if it does not seem relevant. All returns are important as it helps us produce better statistics.
You can provide informed estimates if actual figures are not available.
You can save or print a copy of your answers for your records at the end of this survey.

contents.description: You can preview the questions and some of the guidance before starting the survey. There is more detailed guidance available when you start the survey.
This survey is a key resource for understanding the structure, conduct and performance of businesses across the UK.
View the survey information (this link opens in a new tab)
This survey has the following sections:
This section asks about the period for which your business will be reporting.

description.text: You will be asked to report for {ref_p_start_date} to {ref_p_end_date}. If you are unable to provide figures for this period, you will have the option to choose your own dates.

contents.description: This section asks for information about your business's income.

list: total turnover
retail turnover
other income
environmental turnover

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding total amounts received in subsidies.
This section asks for information about your business's expenditure.

list: employment costs
energy and materials for business use
goods, energy and services bought for resale
services for business use
rates, duties, levies and taxes paid to the government

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding the value of stocks held by your business at the beginning and end of the period.
This section asks for the total value of acquisitions and proceeds from the disposal of capital assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provide services, for more than one year.

list: land for own use
existing buildings and structures for own use, or where you are responsible for non-dwelling maintenance
construction work for own use, or where you are responsible for non-dwelling maintenance
computer software programs and databases, developed by own staff for business use
computer software programs and databases, purchased or developed externally
machinery and equipment
natural resources
other non-produced assets
intellectual property assets
assets acquired under finance lease
work carried out by own staff for business use

contents.description: This section asks for information about your business's international exports and imports of services. This includes income and expenditure.
This section asks for information about your business's international exports and imports of goods.
This section asks for information about your business's research and development.

list: The statistics produced help to improve the overall quality of National Accounts and the measurement of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) (this link opens in a new tab.)

In addition to the National Accounts, the ABS is also used by the Scottish Government and Welsh Government in the compilation of both regional country specific Input and Output tables and Indices of Production.
It also provides a major contribution to the Blue Book, which is produced annually by our National Accounts Team and used to inform HM Treasury in managing economic policy.
View the latest publication produced from this survey (this link opens in a new tab.)

sections.title: How to complete and reporting period

summary.page_title: How to complete and reporting period summary

blocks.page_title: How to complete and reporting period

content.title: How to complete and reporting period

contents.description: The ABS collects information to better understand the structure, conduct and performance of businesses across the UK.
Please read the following information before starting the survey.

list: Questions in this survey ask for figures either for GB or the UK. Instructions will be provided for each section to know which figures to provide.

Questions that ask for UK data should relate to business activity in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, but excludes the Channel Islands and Isle of Man. For GB data, exclude Northern Ireland.
Please round your figures to the nearest £1,000.
If you need to report negative figures for a question, please enter a '0' and include them in your comments at the end of the survey.
Refer to additional guidance accompanying each question for more information.

contents.description: View the survey information (this link opens in a new tab)

contents.title: What activity to include in this survey

contents.description: Any activity outside the UK lasting for more than one year should be excluded from this questionnaire, except all installation activities outside the UK, which should be included regardless of the length of period of the work carried out.

Any work done in connection with overseas contracts where employees travel abroad regularly for short periods should be included and any overseas activity which is deemed to be capital expenditure in that country should be excluded

description.text: You will be asked to report for {ref_p_start_date} to {ref_p_end_date} If you are unable to provide figures for this period, you will have the option to choose your own dates.

title.text: Are you able to report for the calendar year {ref_p_start_date} to {ref_p_end_date}?

description: Your return should cover the calendar year 2023.

contents.description: Did your business only trade for part of the year?
Please select 'No, I need to report for a different period'
Does your business need to report for a different calendar year?
Please select 'No, I need to report for a different period'

options.label: Yes, I can report for this period
options.value: Yes, I can report for this period

options.label: No, I need to report for a different period
options.value: No, I need to report for a different period

blocks.page_title: Calendar year reporting period

in: Yes, I can report for this period

question.title: What dates will you be reporting for?
description: If figures are not available for the calendar year 2023, your return should relate to a 12 month business year that ends between 6 April 2023 and 5 April 2024.

contents.description: Did your business only trade for part of the year?
Please provide figures for the period in which you were trading.
Your return should cover the period from the commencement of your business until 31 December 2023 or, alternatively, any date up to 5 April 2024.
Your return should cover the period 1 January 2023 to the date you ceased to trade or, alternatively, from the beginning of your last business year up to the cessation date.

answers.label: From
To

blocks.page_title: Alternative reporting period
Income section

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's income.

list: turnover, including work in progress
retail turnover
other sources of income
environmental turnover

contents.description: This refers to goods and services that have been partially processed, fabricated, or assembled by the producer but that are not usually sold or turned over to others without further processing. These products include Work in Progress belonging to the unit, even if the products in question are in the possession of third parties.

Equally, products held by the unit which belong to third parties are excluded, as are partially completed structures for which the ultimate owner is deemed to have taken ownership, either by the existence of a contract of sale or purchase, or because the production is for own use.
This section requires figures for business activity within GB. Exclude Northern Ireland business activity.

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, what was {ru_name}'s total turnover from the sale of goods and services?

list: progress payments on work in progress
VAT
selling price of property not purchased in this period
other operating income
insurance claims received

contents.description: This refers to the total amount receivable in respect of invoices raised during the reporting period, for the sales of goods and services. Figures should be given gross of indirect taxes, duties, and levies, except VAT, invoiced to the customer.

answers.label: Total turnover from the sale of goods and services
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

list: all sales of goods, except fixed capital assets, including exports and goods purchased and resold without processing

provision of goods and/or services to other parts of your company or organisation which are not covered by this return. These should be valued as if sold to an independent customer. If you are unable to supply figures on this basis, please value them at transfer cost
income from all industrial and non-industrial services rendered
income from construction activity, even if subcontracted
income derived from the renting of property
amounts received for the right to use patents, trademarks, copyrights, and so on
the value of second-hand goods taken in part exchange, such second-hand goods should also be recorded as purchases
transport, insurance and packaging charges, less amounts for returnable containers, invoiced by your business, even if invoiced separately

for commission work, where you do not hold title to goods sold, the commission or fee is to be included but not the full transaction price. Also to be included here are costs incurred and passed on to the customer
royalty payments received
property bought and sold in the same financial period without development
the value of land and buildings acquired for development and disposed of within a 12 month period
output for own final use
income recorded as extraordinary income in your accounts
amounts received from the sale of fixed capital assets
amounts received from the sale of patents, trademarks, copyrights, and so on
grants from any source
subsidies from UK public authorities and the European Union
value of insurance claims received
income recorded as 'other operating income' in your accounts
all trade, cash or other discounts and rebates, record turnover net of these
income derived from the renting of land, if recorded separately within your accounts
interest payments received and other similar income
the value of land and buildings acquired for development and disposed of after a 12 month period
the value of any work done on buildings for own use, carried out by your own staff
the value of freehold land from selling price
dividends received
amounts arising from donations and fundraising activities
the full value of any transfer fees received

blocks.page_title: Total turnover from the sale of goods and services

title.text: Of {total_turnover_from_the_sale_of_goods_and_services} turnover, what was the value of sales of goods direct to the general public for personal or household use?

description:
An informed estimate is acceptable.

Please give examples of goods sold direct to general public and not businesses for personal or household use in the comments box at the end of the questionnaire.

list: installation services
sales to businesses
sales and repairs to land and properties

answers.label: Turnover from retail sales
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

list: sales of food, confectionery, drinks, envelopes and other stationery, knitting wool, ornaments, toys and games, and so on
installation services on domestic and household appliances only when in combination with sale of goods
retail sale by commission agents
commission on lottery sales
commission from sales of telephone top-up cards

for commission work, where you do not hold title to goods sold, the commission or fee is to be included but not the full transaction price. Also to be included are costs incurred and passed on to the customer
service charges for credit provided but not interest charges
receipts from government for goods and services supplied free, or at a subsidised rate, under the National Health Service and similar public services
income from retail sales over the Internet where you hold title to the goods sold
commission received on sales by other businesses operating on your premises, excluding the total value of the sale
sales of food and drink as a catering activity, including staff canteens, take-away food and bar sales
renting and hiring of goods
sales of services, for example holidays, cinema and other tickets, membership fees
turnover from work on the structure of a building, such as decorating or plumbing
installation services on domestic and household appliances when not in combination with sale of goods

question.title: For the reporting period, what was the value of insurance claims received by your business?
description: This figure should not be included in previous turnover questions.

claims received from sinking fund policies, policies providing pensions, superannuation or other retirement, sickness, personal, accident, and disability or death benefits for employees or their dependants
any claims receivable from re-insurance business written

answers.label: Value of insurance claims received

question.title: For the reporting period, what was the value of your business’s other operating income?
description: This refers to other operating income recorded in your profit and loss and/or income and expenditure accounts. This figure should not be included in previous turnover questions.

list: income derived from the renting of land, if recorded separately within your accounts
interest and dividends
all trade, cash or other discounts and rebates that are recorded in your profit and loss and/or income and expenditure accounts

question.title: Does your business produce goods or services that protect the environment?

contents.description: Goods and/or services that protect the environment that are produced by your business. For example:

list: production or installation of solar panels
waste collection, treatment and disposal services
environmental consultancy and training services

the consumption of recycled materials

Subsidies section

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding the total amounts received in subsidies.
This section requires figures for business activity within GB. Exclude Northern Ireland business activity.

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, what was the total amounts {ru_name} received in subsidies from UK government sources and the European Union (EU)?

list: import and export refunds, for example, under the EU’s Common Agricultural Policy
subsidies on payroll or workforce, such as through the Work and Health Programme, formerly known as the Work Programme

grants received from any source such as UK government bodies, EU, charitable organisations, and so on. Grants are defined as one-off payments received with the intention to lessen the burden of capital expenditure such as new building work or machinery, and so on
receipts from government for goods and services supplied free or at a subsidised rate, under the National Health Service and similar public services
grants to cover historical losses or for the cancellation of debt

definitions.title: What we mean by 'total amounts received in subsidies'

contents.description: This refers to amounts receivable from UK government bodies or the EU to reduce the price of products, or goods or services, sold into a market environment.

answers.label: Total amounts received in subsidies from UK government sources and the EU
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

blocks.page_title: Total amounts received in subsidies

title.text: Of the {total_amounts_received_in_subsidies_from_uk_government_sources_and_the_eu} received in subsidies, what was the value of subsidies received under the Work and Health Programme?

answers.label: Value of subsidies received under the Work and Health Programme
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

blocks.page_title: Value of subsidies received under the Work and Health Programme
Expenditure section

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's expenditure.

list: employment costs
energy and materials for business use
goods and services bought for resale
services for business use
rates, duties, levies and taxes paid to the government

contents.description: For energy, materials and services for business use, and goods and services bought for resale, state the net cost of purchases made during the period of this return whether or not they were used or resold during that period. Valuation should be at full delivered cost. Deductible VAT should be excluded from the cost but non-deductible VAT should be included. In the case of imports the cost should include import and excise duties, less drawback.
This section requires figures for business activity within GB. Exclude Northern Ireland business activity.

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, what was {ru_name}'s expenditure on gross wages and salaries?

description: Wages and salaries are defined as the total compensation in cash or in-kind payable to all employees. State the amount paid before deductions but less any amounts for which you are reimbursed from government sources.

list: national insurance contributions
contributions to other pension and welfare schemes

contents.description: An employee is anyone aged 16 or over that your organisation pays directly from its payroll(s), in return for carrying out a full-time or part-time job or being on a training scheme.

list: all workers such as permanent, temporary, casual and seasonal workers, paid directly from this business's payroll(s)
those temporarily absent but still being paid, for example on parental leave, on holiday, or on sick
former employees only receiving a pension
self-employed workers
subcontractors

answers.label: Expenditure on gross wages and salaries
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

list: all overtime payments, bonuses and commissions
payments to those temporarily absent, for example on parental leave, on holiday, or on sick

the cost to the employer of all expenses and benefits in-kind. These include: assets transferred to employees such as cars, property, goods or other assets; payments made on behalf of employees; mileage allowances and fuel payments, unless the payments are in respect of travelling expenses
employment costs paid to workers employed by the UK company and workers employed who are based overseas. These costs should only reflect the installation services activity carried out outside the UK
any 'signing on' fees paid to employees
accrued holiday pay
payments to working proprietors, partners, and executive directors not in receipt of a regular salary, fee, or commission
travelling and subsistence expenses
amounts paid to subcontractors
payments to homeworkers on piecework rates
redundancy and severance payments
payments to employment agencies for the services of agency staff

definitions.title: What we mean by 'Climate Change Levy'

contents.description: This refers to the Climate Change Levy (CCL), introduced in April 2001, which is charged on industrial and commercial use of various forms of energy, for example, primary and secondary fuel for lighting, heating, motive power and power for appliances.

answers.label: Expenditure on amounts payable directly to government under the Climate Change Levy

question.title: For the reporting period, what was your business's expenditure on other amounts paid for rates, duties, levies and taxes?
description:
You should only include the value for the following rates, duties, levies and taxes if your business paid these directly to government, statutory bodies or regulators.

Do not include these taxes if they were paid as part of your purchase of goods, materials and services.

list: excise duties when paid directly to government by your business. For example, on alcohol, tobacco and hydrocarbon oil fuel duty
stamp duties
export levies, for example, under the EU's Common Agricultural Policy
import duties

regulator fees including any statutory amounts paid to: Environment Agency (EA), Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (OFGEM), Office of Water Service Regulation (OFWAT) in England and Wales and the Scottish Water and Sewerage Customers Council (SWSCC) in Scotland, Office of Communications (OFCOM) and Office of Rail and Road (ORR)
Consumer and Credit Act fees
franchise payments to government, for example, rail franchise premia
EU Emissions Trading System
CRC Energy Efficiency Scheme, formerly known as Carbon Reduction Commitment
renewable energy obligations
sugar levy paid to the European Union
levies paid to government levy-funded bodies, for example, Financial Services Compensation Scheme, Agriculture and Horticulture Development Board and the Sea Fish Industry Authority, and so on
Vehicle Registration Tax, paid upon registering new or imported vehicles for the first time
VAT
Vehicle Exercise Duty or road fund licences
Council Tax payable via local authorities in respect of your rented property
operators’ licences
Petroleum Revenue Tax
net payments to trade associations and similar bodies
Inheritance Tax
Landfill Tax
Insurance Premium Tax
Lottery Duty
Capital Gains Tax
Corporation Tax
Income Tax
fees and other licences, for example, passport, television, boating and fishing
rent payments on land
tax already included in the purchase of goods, materials and services

answers.label: Expenditure on other amounts paid for rates, duties, levies and taxes
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

summary.page_title: Value of stocks held section summary

blocks.page_title: Value of stocks held section

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding the value of stocks held by your business.
This includes the total value of work in progress at the beginning and end of the period.

list: Inventories should be valued on the basis used in your financial statements on the basis of UK GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Principles) or International GAAP.
Where long-term contract balances are included in stocks, they should be recorded net of progress payments.
Where the outcome of the contract is known with reasonable certainty and a proportion of the contract income has been recognised as turnover, progress payments should be disregarded.
Value of stocks held includes Work in Progress but excludes VAT, consignment stock, stock you do not hold title to and progress payments on long-term contracts.

contents.description: This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.

This refers to goods and services that have been partially processed, fabricated, or assembled by the producer but that are not usually sold or turned over to others without further processing. These products include Work in Progress belonging to the unit, even if the products in question are in the possession of third parties.

Equally, products held by the unit which belong to third parties are excluded, as are partially completed structures for which the ultimate owner is deemed to have taken ownership, either by the existence of a contract of sale or purchase, or because the production is for own use.

title.text: What was {ru_name}'s total value of Work in Progress on {from}?

description: The figures for the beginning and end of the period should be on the same basis in terms of valuation and business units covered.

list: all stocks owned and held by you in the UK or currently in transit within the UK
all stocks owned and held by you overseas or currently in transit abroad
products that you own title to in intermediate stages of completion
long term business contract balances with progress payments treated in line with UK GAAP or International GAAP
contracts not yet finalised - commission fees for work carried out
building work carried out by yourselves, including finished properties built by yourselves, with the intention to sell
products in intermediate stages of completion that do not belong to you
VAT
progress payments on long-term contracts

label.text: Value of Work in Progress on {from}

answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

Capital assets section

contents.description: This section asks you to provide the total value of acquisitions and proceeds from the disposal of capital assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provide services, for more than one year.
Information requested may not always be found on a register of capital assets, and should include all assets of any value, even if this is below your Asset Register threshold.

list: land for own use
existing buildings and structures for own use, or where you are responsible for non-dwelling maintenance
construction work for own use, or where you are responsible for non-dwelling maintenance
computer software programs and databases, developed by own staff for business use
computer software programs and databases, purchased or developed externally
machinery and equipment
natural resources
other non-produced assets
intellectual property assets
assets acquired under finance lease
work carried out by own staff for business use

assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provision of services, for more than one year

all work of a capital nature carried out by your own staff, including labour costs and the cost of purchases consumed in work
professional charges and installation costs, and so on, associated with capital assets must be reported with the asset value
assets outside the UK
assets acquired in taking over an existing business or sold as part of a going concern
assets of a capital nature acquired for resale rather than for use within business, for example, stocks of vehicles held by motor traders
assets like TV adverts or copyrights
software licences of up to a year
assets leased to another business under finance lease where repair and maintenance are carried out by the other business, or lessee
assets acquired under an operating lease where responsibility for repair and maintenance is borne by the owner, or lessor, of the asset

any trade or transfer costs invoiced to you separately
non-deductible VAT

capital expenditure at any site belonging to the business where operations have not yet begun
grants and allowances from government sources, statutory bodies or local authorities that have been used to acquire or create assets used in production

progress payment or deposits covering long-term contracts acquiring fixed assets
all work of a capital nature carried out by your own staff, including labour costs and the cost of purchases consumed in work

assets outside the UK

assets of a capital nature acquired for resale rather than for use within business, for example, stocks of vehicles held by motor traders

software licences of up to a year

asset transfers between companies owned by the same enterprise, except where the asset value is considered to be a 'new' acquisition or disposal within the company accounts
interest and instalment payments under finance leasing arrangements

summary.page_title: International trade in services section summary

blocks.page_title: International trade in services section

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's international exports and imports of services. This includes income and expenditure.
This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.

title.text: Of {ru_name}'s total turnover for the period {from} to {to}, what was your business's income from services provided to individuals, enterprises or other organisations based outside the UK?

description:
The UK is defined as England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. It does not include the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man. A subsidiary or parent of your company situated in another country is regarded as an international resident hence transactions in services with these entities should be regarded as international trade in services.

Please provide examples of services provided by individuals, enterprises or other organisations outside of the UK in the comments box at the end of the questionnaire.

list: transactions with branches or subsidiaries of UK businesses that are located outside the UK
transactions with a subsidiary or parent of your company located outside the UK
repair of construction equipment and computers, but not maintenance
operational leasing: the hiring out of plant, machinery and other goods
advertising and commission as an agent, excluding the value of imports or exports of goods
merchanting profits and losses on goods bought and sold abroad without entering the UK
management fees
trade in goods
transactions with branches or subsidiaries of foreign businesses that are located within the UK
dividend or interest payments
transactions in financial assets or liabilities
repairs other than for construction equipment and computers
salaries of staff seconded abroad if the period of their absence is more than one year
business travel services such as accommodation and meals whilst abroad

answers.label: Income from services provided to individuals, enterprises or other organisations based outside the UK
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

Research and development section

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's research and development.
This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.

title.text: Did {ru_name} carry out any in-house research and development for the period {from} to {to}, or intend to do so in the next reporting period?

description: Base your answer on business activity within the UK.

definitions.title: What we mean by 'research and development'

contents.description: Research and Development (R&D) covers three types of activity:

list: Basic research
Applied research
Experimental development

contents.description: R&D comprises creative and systematic work undertaken in order to increase the stock of knowledge, and in order to devise new applications of available knowledge. R&D activity must have elements of all of these five criteria:
Novel - To be aimed at new findings
Creative - To be based on original, not obvious, concepts and hypotheses
Uncertain - To be uncertain about the final outcome
Transferable or reproducible - To lead to results that could possibly be reproduced

blocks.page_title: In-house research and development activities

question.title: Please provide any further details that will help us understand your figures and tell an industry story
description:
Explain any changes in your figures from your previous return, including any negative figures you need to report. If you provide comments, we are less likely to contact you with data queries.

Make sure you continue to the next page and select 'submit answers' at the bottom.

list: any zero figures

contents.description: Any significant impacts upon your data resulting from changes to your business. For example:

list: changes to your business structure
type of activity undertaken

contents.description: Changes in the accounting approaches you have taken. For example:

list: change of accounting standard such as IFRS
regulatory changes
